# Norton Rose Says 'We Don't Talk About Putin-o, No, No, No!'
## Clarity is important.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 1, 2022 at 1:32 PMMarch 1, 2022 at 12:28 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/norton-rose-says-we-dont-talk-about-putin-o-no-no-no/&text=Norton%20Rose%20Says%20‘We%20Don’t%20Talk%20About%20Putin-o,%20No,%20No,%20No!’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/norton-rose-says-we-dont-talk-about-putin-o-no-no-no/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/norton-rose-says-we-dont-talk-about-putin-o-no-no-no/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Chris McGrath/Getty Images)

Biglaw firms really have two good responses when an international crisis shines a light on how they’ve gotten [hip-deep in Russian government clients](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/biglaw-firms-ditching-russian-government-clients-because-its-the-right-move/) (or at least involved with clients facing edicts to cut off existing relationships with Russian entities). First, they can announce that they’re dropping these Russian entities immediately in light of the overwhelming international economic crackdown on Vladimir Putin’s regime. Second, they can keep a low profile while trying to find a [graceful exit strategy](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/03/01/white-case-begins-dropping-russian-clients-405-100240/?kw=White%20%26%20Case%20Begins%20Dropping%20Russian%20Clients&utm_source=email&utm_medium=enl&utm_campaign=newsroomupdate&utm_content=20220301&utm_term=tal) if the specific work carries professional obligations that prevent the firm from dropping the client on a dime.

What firms don’t want to do is make it look like they’ve got something to hide by sending a confusing message to their thousands of attorneys about keeping their mouths shut about what’s going on.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Norton Rose woke up and [chose this route](https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/news/norton-rose-tells-lawyers-no-external-commentary-on-russian-sanctions/5111676.article).

Norton Rose Fulbright has issued an ‘internal notice relating specifically to external commentary on sanctions’, a spokesperson confirmed to the Gazette, adding that the firm has ‘appropriate risk management policies in place across our global business’.

They said: ‘Our sanctions team is advising clients across the world and, given the rapidly evolving situation, it is important that this advice is provided directly, through the appropriate channels. We therefore recently issued an internal notice relating specifically to external commentary on sanctions.

Um… what does that mean? The most generous interpretation is simply that attorneys should decline to offer themselves to the media as experts on the sanctions process while the firm is trying to advise clients directly. Ideally, the firm would clarify that this only relates to sanctions and not the crisis itself.

But without that clarity, the statement certainly seems to suggest “we don’t want to see any NRF employees on social media expressing support for isolating Putin.” As one might imagine, this got people very angry.

And at least one of those people appears to be senior Norton Rose management.

Biglawboiz captured this:



Hopefully, Soliman’s read prevails within Norton Rose.

Because it’s one thing for a sprawling firm to tell lawyers that the right hand shouldn’t offer legal advice to the newspaper while the left hand is trying to sort out a oil and gas forward contract. It’s another to tell the firm to not talk.

# Is It Time To Officially Say Bye-Bye To The Billable Hour Thanks To AI?
## Generative AI may be dipping into your hours....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 27, 2023 at 4:16 PMSeptember 27, 2023 at 2:19 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/is-it-time-to-officially-say-bye-bye-to-the-billable-hour-thanks-to-ai/&text=Is%20It%20Time%20To%20Officially%20Say%20Bye-Bye%20To%20The%20Billable%20Hour%20Thanks%20To%20AI?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/is-it-time-to-officially-say-bye-bye-to-the-billable-hour-thanks-to-ai/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/is-it-time-to-officially-say-bye-bye-to-the-billable-hour-thanks-to-ai/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

In my mind, it’s not a question of whether generative AI will have an impact on law firm reliance on the billable hour, it’s a question of when and where.

— [Jae Um](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jaesunum/), former director of pricing strategy at Baker McKenzie, and founder and executive director at Six Parsecs, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/09/26/is-generative-ai-coming-for-your-billable-hours/) on the role generative artificial intelligence will play on the billable hour within the legal profession. In a recent Legaltech News survey, 45% of respondents said they believed that generative AI would lessen their reliance on the billable hour, while around 15% predicted it wouldn’t, and about 35% didn’t know.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics

# Higher Pay For Fewer Summer Associates -- But Layoffs May Be Looming
## Don't let those cushy paychecks distract you from the underlying news here...
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 6, 2017 at 1:42 PMJuly 6, 2017 at 4:50 PM
19
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/higher-pay-for-fewer-summer-associates-but-layoffs-may-be-looming/&text=Higher%20Pay%20For%20Fewer%20Summer%20Associates%20—%20But%20Layoffs%20May%20Be%20Looming)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/higher-pay-for-fewer-summer-associates-but-layoffs-may-be-looming/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/higher-pay-for-fewer-summer-associates-but-layoffs-may-be-looming/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw summer associate classes have been shrinking, but at some firms, paychecks have grown larger than ever before. At the nearly 100 firms that participated in this year’s summer associates survey conducted by the American Lawyer, summer hiring decreased by an average of 2.02 percent. On the flip side of the coin, law students who managed to be hired for a summer associateship earned an average salary of $3,285 per week, up 11.36 percent from last year.

As usual, firms located in New York City took the lead in terms of the most summer hires (2,175), followed by Chicago (311), Los Angeles (299), and Boston (222). Which firms had the largest increases and decreases in the sizes of their summer classes? Cadwalader had the largest decrease in summer associates on a percentage basis, with 48.9 percent fewer summers (dropping from 47 hires in 2016 to 24 hires in 2017), while Paul Hastings had the largest absolute decrease in summers (dropping from 132 in 2016 to 84 in 2017). Cadwalader said the decrease in hiring was intentional, to ensure that the firm “keep[s] quality up.” Paul Hastings, on the other hand, said 2016 was an “outlier” year, and that the firm’s summer classes tend to be “a bit smaller.”

Ogletree Deakins and Cleary Gottlieb saw the largest percentage increases in summer hires, with Ogletree hiring 83.3 percent more summers in 2017 than the year prior (though the class size only increased from 12 to 22), while Cleary had the largest increase in absolute summers, with 151 law students joining the firm, compared to the 97 the firm hired last year.

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Now, for the moment you’ve been waiting for, the firms with the highest and lowest pay. McKenna Moore of the Am Law Daily elaborates:

Four firms tied for the highest summer associate pay, $3,750 per week: Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson; Dechert; Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel; and Cooley. Tennessee-based Baker, Donelson, Bearman, Caldwell & Berkowitz reported the lowest salary in the survey: $1,500 per week.

Don’t let those cushy paychecks distract you from the underlying news here: there are fewer summer associates for a reason.

According to Eric Seeger of Altman Weil, with clients sending less work to outside counsel, there is decreased demand across Biglaw. “In firms where partners are having a hard time keeping themselves busy, they have less work to throw to associates,” he said.

The bad news doesn’t end there. Survey respondents also said they expected to welcome fewer first-year associates to their firms in the fall, with average class sizes dropping from 40.4 to 38.6. Enjoy those paychecks while you can, summers, because 46 percent of Biglaw firms expect to have the same number of associates or fewer over the next five years.

Are layoffs coming to Biglaw in the future? The writing may already be on the wall, and it doesn’t seem to bode well for associates.

# Latest Biglaw Firm To Raise Associate Salaries Proves Compensation Hikes Aren't Just For The Biggest Firms
## Congrats on the raises!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 18, 2023 at 10:27 AMDecember 18, 2023 at 10:18 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/choate-compensation-23/&text=Latest%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Raise%20Associate%20Salaries%20Proves%20Compensation%20Hikes%20Aren’t%20Just%20For%20The%20Biggest%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/choate-compensation-23/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/choate-compensation-23/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s an easy call for the biggest in Biglaw to match the new associate compensation scale started earlier this year by Milbank and Cravath. Almost more interesting than a mega firm easily matching the raises, are the smaller outfits that are still proving they can keep up with the big dogs on salaries

Take for example the single-office firm, Choate Hall. The firm may have only had $311,956,000 in gross revenue last year, putting it in the second hundred of the Am Law ranking, but they have an impressive profits per equity partner number — over $3 million. Turns out that’s enough to get on board with the raises sweeping through Biglaw. In a Friday announcement, the firm told associates they’d all be getting raises in the new year.

The new compensation scale at the firm is as follows:


The full memo is available on the [next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/choate-compensation-23/2/)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon [@Kathryn1@mastodon.social.](//mastodon.social/@Kathryn1%22)

# Biglaw Managing Partner's #1 Piece Of Advice For Associates
## BE HAPPY! That's an order.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 27, 2017 at 3:15 PMFebruary 28, 2017 at 12:22 PM
2
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/biglaw-managing-partners-1-piece-of-advice-for-associates/&text=Biglaw%20Managing%20Partner’s%20#1%20Piece%20Of%20Advice%20For%20Associates)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/biglaw-managing-partners-1-piece-of-advice-for-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/biglaw-managing-partners-1-piece-of-advice-for-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Jeffrey Lehrer

Keep your sense of humor. Have fun and love your job and never be a grump or treat people poorly.

— [Jeffrey Lehrer](https://www.dlapiper.com/en/us/people/l/lehrer-jeffrey-k/), D.C. managing partner of DLA Piper, on his number 1 piece of advice for young associates. Read the rest of Lehrer’s advice [here](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/02/27/dont-be-a-grump-and-dlas-other-advice-for-associates/).

# Biglaw Firm Conducts Layoffs, Citing 'Shifting Market Dynamics'
## Layoffs continue among even the most successful Biglaw firms.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 16, 2023 at 2:14 PMMarch 16, 2023 at 1:35 PM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/lowenstein-layoffs/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Conducts%20Layoffs,%20Citing%20‘Shifting%20Market%20Dynamics’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/lowenstein-layoffs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/lowenstein-layoffs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Despite predictions of an onslaught of layoffs within the legal industry, the past few weeks have been relatively quiet on the job loss front. Perhaps it’s been a little too quiet. As it turns out, in the wake of bank failures, law firm leaders are still quite worried about the economy, and layoffs are still lurking among us. In fact, an Am Law firm conducted a round of layoffs quite recently.

Lowenstein Sandler — a firm that pulled in $392,080,000 gross revenue in 2021, landing it in 103rd place on the Am Law 200 — has laid off 16 business professionals across three offices in New York, New Jersey, and Washington, D.C., with most of the layoffs affecting the firm’s business development and staff recruiting personnel.

A spokesperson from the firm offered this statement concerning the layoffs:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
“Changing client and attorney support needs, combined with shifting market dynamics, caused us to review our business services group staffing levels across the firm. As a result of this review, we made the difficult decision to separate from 16 of our business services professionals. We are grateful to each of these professionals for the valuable contributions made to the firm during their tenure and we are providing outplacement support and resources as they look for other opportunities.”

According to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/03/16/lowenstein-lays-off-16-business-professionals-in-multiple-offices/), Lowenstein had quite a successful year in 2022, with gross revenue climbing by more than 15%, revenue per lawyer growing by 12.5%, and profits per equity partner increasing by nearly 27%. Following such a strong financial performance, you’d think layoffs would be off the table for a firm that’s likely to break into the Am Law 100 this year.

Best of luck to those who are being let go from Lowenstein Sandler.

If your firm or organization is reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs) or text us ([646-820-8477](tel:646-820-8477)).

# Federal Judge Does Not Take Kindly To Biglaw Firm Calling Him Names
## The judge was not about to let this roll off his back.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 22, 2020 at 3:15 PMJuly 23, 2020 at 8:59 AM
24
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/federal-judge-does-not-take-kindly-to-biglaw-firm-calling-him-names/&text=Federal%20Judge%20Does%20Not%20Take%20Kindly%20To%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Calling%20Him%20Names)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/federal-judge-does-not-take-kindly-to-biglaw-firm-calling-him-names/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/federal-judge-does-not-take-kindly-to-biglaw-firm-calling-him-names/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Oh this is fantastic. It’s really the best kind of benchslap because you don’t need to know any details about the case to understand the devastating slap this federal judge dropped on the Biglaw firm of Gibson Dunn.

The defendant, One Technologies, is represented by Gibson Dunn, led by partner Brian Robison, and co-counsel, Lynn Pinker Hurst & Schwegmann. In a brief, a reply in support of a motion for reconsideration, defense counsel referred to district court judge [Sam A. Lindsay’s ](http://www.txnd.uscourts.gov/judge/district-judge-sam-lindsay)interpretation as “nonsensical,” and well, he does not take kindly to that. He analogizes — with citations — using “nonsensical” to calling him stupid, and that is a pretty glaring no-no in the judge’s book.

Take a look at the full benchslap:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Before the court addresses the parties’ arguments, it addresses the statement of counsel for Defendants that the court’s prior interpretation was “nonsensical,” among other things. Defs.’ Reply 1-2. The court takes no umbrage with an attorney disagreeing with its rulings, as at least one party will usually always be adversely affected by what the court does. Disagreement is not uncommon in a highly competitive legal environment. If an attorney believes that the court has made an incorrect ruling concerning a client, the attorney may take advantage of the appellate process.

Defendants’ attorneys’ tone and use of the word “nonsensical” are “beyond the pale.” The court considers the term “nonsensical” to be synonymous with “stupid” and the functional equivalent of using the term “B.S.” This understanding is supported by Merriam Webster’s Collegiate Dictionary. That Defendants’ counsel would display such effrontery to the court is astounding. In any event, if similar conduct recurs, the court will address such conduct with appropriate sanctions, as it will not tolerate such impertinent conduct. The court places the fault squarely at the feet of Defendants’ counsel, as they are responsible for filing documents, as well as the content therein, with the court. The court now addresses the substantive arguments made by the parties.

So everyone with cases in the Northern District of Texas, update your practice manuals and don’t ever, ever call Judge Lindsay, or any of his arguments, nonsensical again.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.
By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Associate Bonus Watch: Davis Polk To The Rescue?
## Is it 2014 all over again?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onNovember 29, 2016 at 6:34 PMNovember 30, 2016 at 1:12 PM
14
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-davis-polk-to-the-rescue/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20Watch:%20Davis%20Polk%20To%20The%20Rescue?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-davis-polk-to-the-rescue/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-davis-polk-to-the-rescue/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Alas, no. This is not a replay of 2014, when Davis Polk [beat Simpson Thacher](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/associate-bonus-watch-davis-polk-beats-simpson/) and set the new bonus market. It’s a repeat of 2015, when DPW [dutifully followed Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-davis-polk-announces/).

And you know what? People are fine with that. As one tipster told us, “Reaction is neither happy nor sad.” Said a second source, “As expected.” As we mentioned in our initial story about the [Cravath bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2016-associate-bonuses/), when you combine the summer pay raises with holding the line on bonuses, associates end up doing better this year than last.

Of course, even though these bonuses are nice, hope springs eternal in the debt-saddled law graduate’s breast. Is it possible the bonus scale could go higher? As I wrote [back in 2015](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/where-are-the-biglaw-bonuses-associate-bonus-watch-day-3/):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
There are, at most, five firms with any role to play in setting compensation for the top-shelf, New York-focused, lockstep firms — a compensation scale that then becomes the benchmark for Biglaw around the country. I will call these firms the “Fab Five”: Cravath (the usual first mover), Davis (last year’s scale setter), Simpson (last year’s first mover), Skadden (2008’s first mover), and Sullivan & Cromwell (which hasn’t been a player super-recently, but I’m giving them credit for [making spring bonuses happen](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/01/associate-bonus-watch-sullivan-cromwell-pays-generous-spring-bonuses/) back in 2011).

At this point, we’ve heard from three of the five: Cravath, Simpson, and Davis. If anyone trumps Cravath, it will be S&C or SASMF. If they both match, then game over.

Do you work at Skadden or Sullivan? When your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”). We always keep our sources on bonus stories anonymous. There’s no need to send the memo using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. Please be sure to include the memo as proof; we like to post complete bonus memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. You can also text us if you prefer, at 646-820-8477.

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks!

# Associates At This Am Law 100 Firm Will Be Swimming In Money Thanks To These Raises
## Come take a dip in this pool of money, associates!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 25, 2021 at 10:48 AMJune 25, 2021 at 10:53 AM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/jenner-raise-2021/&text=Associates%20At%20This%20Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Will%20Be%20Swimming%20In%20Money%20Thanks%20To%20These%20Raises)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/jenner-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/jenner-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Every day since June 10 has been an especially great day to be a Biglaw associate in America. It was on that day that [Milbank](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/milbank-raises-21/) raised salaries, and on June 11, [Davis Polk](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/davis-polk-salary-21/) raised the bar even higher. Since then, associates have been waiting to see when their firm would allow them to dive into a gigantic pool of money on the new $205K salary scale.

To that end, Jenner & Block — ranked at No. 88 in the most recent Am Law 100 — had some great news for associates yesterday. The Chicago-based firm brought in $446,295,000 gross revenue in 2020, and now it’s bringing associates some big raises for their hard work during the pandemic. Here’s what the Davis Polk match looks like at Jenner:

- 2021: $202,500
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
As noted in the firm’s memo, associates beyond the class of 2014 as well as special counsel will receive word separately about their salary increases.

Congratulations to everyone at Jenner & Block!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Jenner & Block.)

Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs.
